Award.AwardTitle: Gravitational Physics via Lunar Laser Ranging: Optimizing Data Quality
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gravity, the most evident force of nature, is in fact the weakest of the fundamental forces, and consequently the most poorly tested. Einstein's general relativity, which is currently our best description of gravity, is fundamentally incompatible with quantum mechanics and is likely to be replaced by a more complete theory in the future. A modified theory would predict small deviations in the solar system that could have profound consequences for our understanding of the Universe as a whole. Lunar laser ranging (LLR), in which short laser pulses launched from a telescope are bounced off of reflectors placed on the moon by U.S. astronauts and Soviet landers, has for decades produced various leading tests of gravity by mapping the shape of the lunar orbit to high precision. The group proposes to continue conducting leading-edge observations with the Apache Point Observatory Lunar Laser-ranging Operation (APOLLO), in an effort to subject gravity to the most stringent tests yet. APOLLO, situated atop a 9,200 ft summit in Southern New Mexico, introduces a new regime of millimeter-precision in measuring the lunar orbit. However, incomplete models are thus far unable to confirm the accuracy. The group will therefore seek to build a calibration system to ensure that APOLLO meets its millimeter measurement goal, in addition to continuing the observation campaign. The proposed work will benefit the broader community in a number of ways. On the intellectual front, improving our knowledge of gravity informs a diverse range of cosmologists, astrophysicists, particle physicists, and string theorists. The effort would also contribute to Earth and planetary science, especially via measurements produced by the superconducting gravimeter. The APOLLO team will continue a track record of engagement in education and outreach activities, and will no doubt continue to attract public interest through print, web, radio, and television media.

Among other attributes that contribute to APOLLO's superior observations, routine ranging to all five lunar reflectors on timescales of minutes dramatically improves our ability to gauge lunar orientation and body distortion. This information allows a more precise determination of the path for the Moon's center of mass, thereby facilitating tests of fundamental gravity. Simultaneously, higher precision range measurements, together with data from a superconducting gravimeter at the Apache Point Observatory and from a high-quality Global Positioning System (GPS) station 2.5 km away, will greatly improve our understanding of the instantaneous location of the Observatory with respect to the Earth's center of mass (needed for the gravitational tests) by exposing subtle Earth dynamics that must be incorporated into the model. LLR measurements provide the best available tests of the strong equivalence principle, the time-rate-of-change of Newton's gravitational constant, gravitomagnetism, the inverse-square law, and preferred frame effects. In addition to these classical gravitational tests, APOLLO will permit testing of new ideas in physics relating to dark energy, extra dimensions, and violations of Lorentz Invariance. A large part of the effort proposed here is the construction of an absolute calibration system based on a cesium clock standard, a low-jitter short-pulse laser, and a precision interval counter. This system will provide an independent check of APOLLO's fundamental measurement, potentially identifying faults and confirming their pursuant remediation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF grant titled "Testing Gravity Using Millimeter Accuracy Data from APOLLO" supported two main thrusts, both related to the technique of Lunar Laser Ranging (LLR) using the Apache Point Observatory Lunar Laser-ranging Operation (APOLLO).  One thrust involved collection of the highest-quality LLR data in the world as a means to test the fundamental underpinnings of how gravity works, while the other aimed to develop a new apparatus capable of calibrating the APOLLO apparatus so that measurements could be made at one-millimeter accuracy.

We all have a sense for how gravity works: the earth pulls us toward its center and keeps us on the ground.  Isaac Newton established a mathematical formula that was remarkably able to describe gravity throughout the solar system and beyond to such extraordinary fidelity that we still use it for almost all applications, such as solar system navigation.  However, Albert Einstein developed a new vision for gravity founded on a quest to satisfy constancy of the speed of light, and striving for mathematical consistency independent of an observer's state of motion (velocity).  The result is general relativity, differing only subtly from Newtonian gravity so that it is very difficult to see any daylight between them, in ordinary activities. 

Yet, careful tests time after time show that Einstein had the right idea, and that gravity obeys general relativity and not Newton's formula.  LLR offers a pristine gravitational laboratory, for which the difference between Newtonian predictions and the prescription of general relativity modify the shape of the orbit at the 10 meter level.  By measuring to millimeter accuracy, APOLLO can not only clearly see relativistic effects in the lunar orbit (insisting that we abandon Newtonian gravity), it can test whether general relativity is getting the story right.  This is a classic example of how science works: letting the actual universe decide whether or not our ideas are correct.  Physicists have many reasons to suspect that Einstein will not have the last word on gravity; among the reasons is that general relativity and quantum mechanics, the two pillars of modern physics, are fundamentally incompatible with each other, as currently formulated.  Thus the overall goal of the APOLLO project is to provide unprecedented measurement accuracy in our best laboratory for precision tests of gravity.

Because APOLLO provides the best available measurements of the earth-moon distance worldwide, and because elucidation of the science is best served by the longest possible continuous observation record, one priority during the grant period was continued collection of high-quality data.  During the course of the award, APOLLO averaged abut 300 independent measurements per year between the earth station in New Mexico and the the five reflectors on the moon (three left by Apollo astronauts, and two on rovers landed by the Soviet Union).  Because the goal is to map the shape of the lunar orbit, spacing measurements apart by several days is sufficient.  Each clear observation session (about an hour) typically results in of 5 to 10 measurements to the various reflectors.

But the main and most exciting effort in this grant period was the design, construction, and deployment of an absolute calibration system (ACS) capable of pinning down the APOLLO measurement to millimeter accuracy.  This is accomplished by injecting into the APOLLO detector faint pulses of laser light at well-defined times as reference marks.  The laser generates 80 million pulses per second, and is held to this rigid schedule by an atomic clock (cesium), so that the pulses become like calibrated "tick marks" on a ruler in time.  By overlaying this "ruler" onto the normal ranging operation, APOLLO receives signals from both the moon and the ACS through the exact same detector and electronics, at essentially the same time.  In doing so, the APOLLO measurements can be calibrated back to the atomic clock without concern for distortions imposed by the detector and electronics, since those exact same distortions apply to both lunar and ACS signals.

The initial proposal called for a simple scheme of "pulse-on-demand" calibration, in which pulse pairs would be generated roughly 2.5 seconds apart (matching the round-trip light-time to the moon).  Then the APOLLO-determined time measurement would be compared to the "truth" value that went into generating the pulse pair.  But as the grant period started, the team hit upon the far superior approach of a continuous stream of calibration pulses, tied rigidly to an atomic clock.  This permitted the powerful superposition of ACS atop LLR measurements.

The ACS has worked remarkably well, allowing millimeter-accurate LLR measurements for the first time.  In due course, this should translate into the best-ever constraints on (or possible deviation of) general relativity.
